title: Some compatibility issues
body:
Hi,

I noticed that you have used `onReceivedError(WebView view, WebResourceRequest request, WebResourceError error)` in the class `BrowserActivity` to show a network error in webview window.

For your reference, `onReceivedError(WebView view, WebResourceRequest request, WebResourceError error)` is added in API version 23. For the devices with API version <=22, `onReceivedError(WebView view, WebResourceRequest request, WebResourceError error)` does not work because there is no such a method. (See this [link](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32769505/webviewclient-onreceivederror-deprecated-new-version-does-not-detect-all-errors))

A possible fix is to add deprecated method `void onReceivedError (WebView view, int errorCode,String description,String failingUrl)` since this method supports all API versions.

Hope this information can help you. Thanks.

title: Improvements to URL list management for web_connectivity
body:
We would like to improve how URL lists are managed inside of web_connectivity. The main things we would like to support are:

1. Allowing users to choose which categories they are going to be testing when running ooniprobe on mobile
2. Testing also the country specific lists together with the global list

Before outlining my proposes solution I would like to take a step back and thing of this from a user perspective.

As a ooniprobe user when I choose the categories to be tested and click on the web connectivity "Run" button what I am most interested in is:

a. If any site of the categories I have picked there is blocked on my network
b. Contribute more measurements of that type to the ooniprobe dataset

Given the limitations on mobile we don't actually scan the full list but in most cases (with the default timeout of 90 seconds) will likely be testing only about a dozen sites in total.

URL lists are by nature something that is dynamic so in coming up with a solution for this we should take this into account and it's probably not ideal to have to make a new app release in order to update the testing lists (this is why ooniprobe on desktop, for example, has a dynamic resources update system).

In light of a., maybe we don't actually want to give users all URLs to test, but maybe we want to give them a set that includes some known blocked websites (to give them gratification when they find them to be blocked by running the app) and also some URLs that have not been tested, to improve the ooni dataset (b.).

Given these requirements and reasoning, this is starting do sound a lot like probe orchestration. So what if the running of web connectivity was simply a special orchestration request for accepting a task that is going to be run immediately?

The workflow would look something like the following:

* User configures some settings and chooses which categories of sites they want to test
* Client sends request to orchestration system saying "I am from country XX, I want to test these categories and my test runtime is YY, give me some URLs"
* Orchestration system compiles a list of URLs that includes only the categories chosen by the user, long enough to take at least YY to run, but not too long to not waste bandwidth and returns it to the probe
* The probe takes the URLs and runs the test

Thoughts?

title: Test a random sample of URLs from all 31 categories (included in Citizen Lab repo)
label: [Label(name="wishlist")]
body:
Currently ooniprobe's mobile app tests a random sample of URLs from the Citizen Lab's global test list every time the user runs Web Connectivity. This means that, in some cases, users might only be testing pornographic sites (or other sites that might be of less interest to them), instead of testing "more interesting" sites (such as news media, human rights sites, etc.).

A quick fix to this problem could be re-configuring the web connectivity test to test a random sample of URLs that are fetched from all 31 categories (https://github.com/citizenlab/test-lists/blob/master/lists/00-LEGEND-new_category_codes.csv). That way, a user tests a little bit of everything every time he/she runs web connectivity.

title: More explicit "view log", like in iOS
label: [Label(name="usability"), Label(name="wishlist")]
body: While replying to detailed feedback we received, I noticed that the feature for viewing logs is too much hidden on Android, as compared to iOS (see https://github.com/TheTorProject/ooniprobe-ios/issues/103 for a screenshot). It would be nice if, instead, it would be possible to view logs as easily as we do on iOS.

title: Show only logs of a specific input
label: [Label(name="question"), Label(name="usability"), Label(name="wishlist")]
body:
User story: I am an advanced user, I have run a test, I have seen some anomalies and I'd like to understand more one of them, hence I'd like to see only logs related to such anomaly.

xref: https://github.com/measurement-kit/measurement-kit/issues/1160, https://github.com/TheTorProject/ooniprobe-ios/issues/102

title: Unclear how to get test methodology information
label: [Label(name="question"), Label(name="usability"), Label(name="wishlist")]
body:
User story: I am an advanced user, I end up in the Run Tests section where I am clearly hinted to hit the Run button to start tests, then I am hinted to go into the Past Tests section, where I can see results; at this point, I see anomalies that I think should not be anomalies, and I don't have a quick way to see the test methodology from the results (not to mention that it's not obvious to me that I can get info on a specific test by going on the Run Tests section and running it).

(*IMHO* this history seems to suggest that the place where one may want to know about the methodology is indeed when he/she is looking at results, no?)

xref: https://github.com/TheTorProject/ooniprobe-ios/issues/101

title: web_connectivity: allow to visit specific URL
label: [Label(name="question"), Label(name="usability"), Label(name="wishlist")]
body:
User story: I am a user, I see that a site is an anomaly, I really can't believe it, and I want to see for myself whether that site is actually blocked, by opening it in the browser, and perhaps after that I may also want to provide some sort of feedback to the app developers.

[Edit: maybe this works best for the converse case where I see that a site is not treated as an anomaly, but I know it's somehow blocked in my country (i.e. with a blockpage) and I really want to check right away what I can see from my phone, and possibly report a false negative.]

xref: https://github.com/TheTorProject/ooniprobe-ios/issues/100

title: web_connectivity: allow to repeating test for selected URLs
label: [Label(name="question"), Label(name="usability"), Label(name="wishlist")]
body:
User story: I am a user of the app, I have seen anomalies for a specific set of URLs, there is one URL that I am really surprised to see showing an anomaly, and I want to re-run the test for such URL only, to understand whether we're talking about a transient error or a real anomaly.

xref: https://github.com/TheTorProject/ooniprobe-ios/issues/99

title: Changing color used to indicate anomalies?
label: [Label(name="question"), Label(name="usability"), Label(name="wishlist")]
body:
I was discussing with a user that submitted a long and informative bug report and he/she was commenting that red is, in his/her opinion, too aggressive for what we consider anomalies, as red is usually used to indicate very-bad-things. He maintains that perhaps yellow or pink would better convey the meaning of "look closely at this". I think this makes sense.

xref: https://github.com/TheTorProject/ooniprobe-ios/issues/97

title: Add mobile deep linking support
body:
This was a request from a user.

The basic idea is that I want to invite people to test the reachability of my site say `http://example.com`. When a certain site I want to embed on this page a button that the user can click on and it will:

1. If the app is installed open the app and run the specified test against the url `http://example.com`/ (by first showing confirmation that the specified test is about to run on that site).

2. If the app is not installed redirect me to the market so I can install the app

I believe this can be done by registering a custom schema in the app.

See: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3469908/make-a-link-in-the-android-browser-start-up-my-app

Edit: It seems like this thing has a name: [Mobile Deep Linking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_deep_linking)

title: Add support for Farsi (text displayed from right to left)
label: [Label(name="usability"), Label(name="wishlist")]
body: Elections in Iran are approaching (April 2017) and it would be good to have translated the app to Farsi in advance. However, a prerequisite is adding support for Farsi so that text can be displayed from right to left.

title: Compile everything from scratch for f-droid
body:
The pre-requisite is to have a Linux system with NDK installed. We have been compiling for Android using macOS for quite some time now (my Ubuntu box died ten months ago).

Anyway (this is a *ghetto* procedure to have it compiled, we will make the process more smooth with also the use case of f-droid in mind in subsequent releases):

# clone the repositories
- git clone --branch stable https://github.com/measurement-kit/measurement-kit
- git clone --branch release/v0.4.0 https://github.com/measurement-kit/android-libs
- git clone --branch f-droid https://github.com/TheTorProject/ooniprobe-android

# cross compile dependencies
- cd measurement-kit
- ./build/android/dependency *path-to-ndk-dir* geoip
- ./build/android/dependency *path-to-ndk-dir* libressl
- ./build/android/dependency *path-to-ndk-dir* libevent
- ./build/android/archive-deps  # ignore gpg error [1]
- sign generated archive with your pgp key

# cross compile measurement-kit
- cd ../android-libs
- cp ../measurement-kit/*archive* .
- cp ../measurement-kit/*archive*.asc .
- *make sure that the Makefile mentions exactly the same archive name* [2]
- make dist NDK_BUILD=*path-to-ndk-build*  # ignore pgp error [1]
- sign the generated archive with your pgp key

# move MK and dependencies into app
- cd ../ooniprobe-android
- cp ../android-libs/*archive* .  # not the dependencies the measurement_kit named archive
- cp ../android-libs/*archive*.asc .
- *make sure the Makefile mentions exactly the same archive name* [2]
- make unpack
- gradle build  # I think

[1] I hope you are not able to sign things on my behalf using my pgp key :)
[2] if the name is correct, the Makefile does not download it

title: Prototype Android application (try 2)
body:
This prototype Android application is based on the new repository hosting Measurement Kit JNI libs available at:

```
https://github.com/bassosimone/measurement-kit-jni-libs
```

The implementation uses the JNI libs and their interface to run in synchronous mode OONI tests. The basic mechanism to run in background (inside a so-called service) and to notify back the main thread when work is done is already implemented.

Compared to #1, this is significantly simpler in terms of JNI code and interfaces involved.

title: Prototype app
label: [Label(name="enhancement"), Label(name="help wanted")]
body:
This pull request introduces the prototype Android app. There are still number of limitations, such as that currently tests cannot run in parallel. However this is already used by me on the emulator as well as on a real Android device (Nexus 7 using Android 5.1.1).

This pull request currently contains also the _devpack_ for Android generated using MeasurementKit. I've not figured out yet whether this is the optimal way to bundle it with the application (I dislike adding binary libraries to master because they weight quite a lot -- for this reason for now I've included only x86 and armeabi, rather than including all the available architectures).

---

Note: the `io/github/measurement_kit/{common,ooni}` dirs are copied from measurement-kit's main repository. I don't know if this is the best approach. Open-peer provided the `.class` files, but I thought providing the sources was more transparent to the user.
